items.title: WATCH: ISS astronauts return to Earth early due to illness of crew member, a first
items.summary_auto: NASA’s Crew-11 is returning to Earth today, cutting short their six-month stint in space after an unknown crew member suffered an undisclosed medical condition.

items.title: As Iranians bury their dead, many are waiting for Trump's next move
items.summary_auto: CBC News was able to reach out to a few Iranians to hear their experience and perspective as the country remains cut off from the internet.

items.title: CFL rules committee proposes end to regular-season tie games
items.summary_auto: The CFL rules committee is proposing the elimination of tie games during the regular season.

items.title: Canadian men's soccer head coach seeking contract extension prior to start of World Cup in June
items.summary_auto: Jesse Marsch, the head coach of Canada’s men’s soccer team, wants to extend his contract before the start of the World Cup in June.

items.title: Canadian men's soccer coach Jesse Marsch seeking contract extension prior to start of World Cup in June
items.summary_auto: Jesse Marsch, the head coach of Canada’s men’s soccer team, wants to extend his contract before the start of the World Cup in June.

items.title: U.S. freezing immigrant visa processing for 75 countries, including Iran and Russia
items.summary_auto: The U.S. State Department said Wednesday it will suspend the processing of immigrant visas for citizens of 75 countries, including Afghanistan, Iran, Russia and Somalia, whose nationals the Trump administration has deemed likely to require public assistance while living in the United States.

items.title: Bonnie Crombie formally resigns as Ontario Liberal Party leader
items.summary_auto: Bonnie Crombie has formally announced her resignation as leader of the Ontario Liberal Party, effective immediately. The move comes months after Crombie first announced her intention to resign.

items.title: U.S. unveils Palestinian technocratic group to administer post-war Gaza
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's special envoy, Steve Witkoff, on Wednesday announced the establishment of a technocratic Palestinian body that will play a role in administering the war-ravaged territory under a phased U.S. plan for Gaza's future.

items.title: Canadian skeleton racers support coach's decision that drew ire of other athletes, countries
items.summary_auto: Canadian skeleton racers Madeline Parra and Brielle Durham say they were comfortable with their coach's decision to pull them from a race in a move that's created friction between countries trying to qualify athletes for the Olympic Games.

items.title: CBC News further expands local journalism, bureaus
items.summary_auto: This year, CBC News will add 33 local journalists and create 11 new bureaus, increasing its Canadian footprint from 66 to 77 locations.

items.title: Soldiers, plumbers, volunteers begin to restore homes in Pimicikamak Cree Nation
items.summary_auto: Canadian Armed Forces personnel have arrived in Pimicikamak Cree Nation to help in the aftermath of a devastating power outage that damaged hundreds of homes when several water pipes broke. Plumbers are working on each home while local leadership gather food and supplies.

items.title: Louvre hikes ticket prices by 45% for most non-European visitors
items.summary_auto: The Louvre is putting a higher price on attendees, raising admission prices on Wednesday for most non-European visitors by nearly half as it tries to shore up finances after repeated strikes, chronic overcrowding — and a brazen French Crown Jewels heist that shook the institution.

items.title: BTS is coming back to Canada with 2 Toronto concerts. Here's how you can snag tickets
items.summary_auto: Canadian BTS fans don’t need Permission to Dance as they get excited for the K-pop group’s newly announced world tour, which includes a two-night stop in Toronto.

items.title: BTS fans ecstatic for 2 Toronto concerts in newly announced world tour
items.summary_auto: Canadian BTS fans don’t need Permission to Dance as they get excited for the K-pop group’s newly announced world tour, which includes a two-night stop in Toronto.

items.title: Quebec Premier François Legault resigns ahead of fall provincial elections
Trump gave a Ford plant worker the finger. The White House says it was appropriate
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump raised his middle finger and appeared to direct profanity toward a factory worker who expressed criticism of his handling of the Jeffrey Epstein controversy at a Michigan auto plant on Tuesday, video circulating online showed.

items.title: Foster mom in Ontario murder trial says she did nothing to kill boy in her and wife’s care
'Long way to recovery' for Sapotaweyak Cree Nation girl injured in bus crash, mother says
items.summary_auto: A Sapotaweyak Cree Nation mother says her 16-year-old daughter has "a long way to recovery" after suffering broken bones when a school bus crashed along an icy stretch of rural Manitoba highway on Tuesday.

items.title: Saks Global files for bankruptcy after Neiman Marcus takeover leads to financial collapse
items.summary_auto: High-end department store conglomerate Saks Global filed for bankruptcy protection late on Tuesday, in one of the largest retail collapses since the pandemic. It comes barely a year after a deal that brought Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus under the same roof.

items.title: Denmark, Greenland bring united front to White House as Trump says NATO needs U.S. to control island
items.summary_auto: Officials from Greenland and Denmark met in Washington on Wednesday with top White House officials as U.S. President Donald Trump moved to ratchet up the pressure by suggesting that NATO should help the United States acquire the world's largest island, saying anything less than it being under American control is unacceptable.

items.title: Pilot project aims to address health record headaches for those living near Alberta-Saskatchewan boundary
items.summary_auto: A new Alberta government pilot project is hoping to address a common challenge facing citizens accessing health care in a city that straddles two provinces.

items.title: Ontario man reaches settlement with Boeing over family's death in 2019 Ethiopia plane crash
items.summary_auto: An Ontario man has reached a settlement agreement with Boeing nearly seven years after six of his family members died in a plane crash.

items.title: Iran warns of retaliation if Trump strikes, as U.S. withdraws some personnel from Mideast bases
items.summary_auto: The United States is withdrawing some personnel from bases in the Middle East, a U.S. official said on Wednesday, after a senior Iranian official said Tehran had warned neighbours it would hit American bases if Washington strikes.

items.title: This 90-year-old says an emergency call bell saved her life. Her seniors apartment has since removed it
items.summary_auto: The emergency call bell system in Chelsey Park's independent living building was disconnected in October 2025, leaving residents without a way to get help quickly. The residence is now recommending people buy their own cell phones or personal alarm systems instead.

items.title: To make New Year's resolutions stick, science can work in your favour
items.summary_auto: Most of us abandon New Year's resolutions within four months. But experts say it doesn’t have to be that way — and if you want to make your good intentions stick, there are ways to use science to work in your favour.

items.title: Northern communities see fastest-growing homelessness rates in Ontario, new report says
items.summary_auto: Nearly 85,000 people were known to be experiencing homelessness province-wide last year — about an eight per cent rise over the previous year — and northern and rural regions are driving that growth, a new report from Ontario's municipalities shows. Officials at shelters in northen Ontario communities say those numbers reflect the demands they've seen on the ground.

items.title: 2025 continues streak of hottest years ever recorded
items.summary_auto: 2025 ranked as the third hottest year on record, barely behind the last two years, and one where regions of the world still saw dangerous and deadly heatwaves.

items.title: Air Canada ordered to compensate Ottawa man $15K after losing appeal
items.summary_auto: Roughly three and a half years after an Ottawa man’s flight to Portugal was delayed by over 24 hours, the Ontario Superior Court has ordered Air Canada to pay Rejean Landry $15,000 in compensation.

items.title: Windsor, Ont.-made Dodge Charger wins Car of the Year Award at the Detroit Auto Show
items.summary_auto: The Dodge Charger  —  made in Windsor, Ont. — has been named car of the year at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

items.title: Toronto-area care home resident attacked, mother says, as support worker strike approaches 2 months
items.summary_auto: The mother of a resident of a care home west of Toronto says he was attacked by another resident while support workers from the facility remain on strike after almost two months. The attack comes after the death of another resident at the same facility in December.

items.title: Ontario's largest greenhouse gas emitter quietly extends 'green' steel timeline from 2028 to 2050, gets $50M more from Ottawa
items.summary_auto: Dofasco and the federal government owe the city an explanation about what's actually happening with the decarbonization plans, says a Hamilton resident, as the changes raise more questions than answers.

items.title: Quebec on pace to record back-to-back years with 600 drug overdose deaths
items.summary_auto: Quebec is projected to surpass 600 drug overdose deaths for a second consecutive year and experts are repeating calls for the province to do more to curb this trend.

items.title: Some Canadians are ready to work in Venezuela‘s oilpatch — if they're allowed in
items.summary_auto: In Alberta, there is excitement and hesitation from businesses and energy workers at the potential opportunity ahead in Venezuela.

items.title: Saab wants Canada to buy 72 fighter jets and 6 surveillance aircraft from Sweden to create 12,600 jobs
items.summary_auto: The Canadian Armed Forces would need to buy 72 Gripen fighter jets and six GlobalEye surveillance aircraft for Swedish manufacturer Saab to deliver on its pledge of creating 12,600 jobs in Canada, CBC News has learned.

items.title: Hurricane hunter planes turn their sights to atmospheric rivers
items.summary_auto: Atmospheric rivers — and the flooding they bring — are intensifying with climate change. For the past decade, the same hurricane hunter planes used to study cyclones have been flying straight into these West Coast rain-makers. Why? Because the data they collect proves these flights can significantly improve forecasts. CBC’s Johanna Wagstaffe looks at how that evidence is driving a major expansion of the program.

items.title: At least 29 dead after crane collapses onto passenger train in Thailand
items.summary_auto: The crane, which was being used to construct an elevated highspeed railway, fell onto the moving train causing it to derail and catch fire.

items.title: Kiefer Sutherland arrested after alleged assault in Los Angeles
items.summary_auto: Actor Kiefer Sutherland was arrested early Monday morning after Los Angeles police responded to a call reporting an assault involving a ride-hail driver, authorities said.

items.title: It's big, beautiful and — blue. But this 40-year-old iceberg is about to disappear for good
items.summary_auto: An iceberg that was once the biggest on the planet is floating off into the South Atlantic Ocean, where it will soon melt away into watery oblivion. But it's going out in style.
